maml:description.maml:para: Add common name or thumbprint to the cluster for client authentication purposes.
Use Add-AzServiceFabricClientCertificate to add a common name and issuer thumbprint or certificate thumbprint to the cluster, so the client can use it for authentication.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster
Client authentication type
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Specify client certificate thumbprint
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster
Client authentication type
Specify client certificate common name
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Specify thumbprint of client certificate's issuer
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster
Specify client certificate thumbprint which only has admin permission
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Specify client certificate thumbprint which only has read only permission
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster
Specify client common name , issuer thumbprint and authentication type
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Client authentication type
Specify client certificate thumbprint which only has admin permission
Specify client common name , issuer thumbprint and authentication type
Specify client certificate common name
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Specify thumbprint of client certificate's issuer
Specify the name of the cluster
Specify client certificate thumbprint which only has read only permission
Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify client certificate thumbprint
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:> Add-AzServiceFabricClientCertificate -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -Thumbprint 5F3660C715EBBDA31DB1FFDCF508302348DE8E7A -Admin

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will add the certificate with thumbprint '5F3660C715EBBDA31DB1FFDCF508302348DE8E7A' to the cluster, so the client can use the certificate as admin to communicate with the cluster.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:> Add-AzServiceFabricClientCertificate -ResourceGroupName 'Group2' -Name 'Contoso02SFCluster' -CommonName 'Contoso.com' -IssuerThumbprint 5F3660C715EBBDA31DB1FFDCF508302348DE8E7A

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will add a read only client certificate that's common name is 'Contoso.com' and issuer thumbprint is '5F3660C715EBBDA31DB1FFDCF508302348DE8E7A' to the cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Add a secondary cluster certificate to the cluster.

Use Add-AzServiceFabricClusterCertificate to add a secondary cluster certificate, either from an existing Azure key vault or creating a new Azure key vault using an existing certificate provided or from a new self-signed certificate created. It will override the secondary cluster if there is any.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster
Certificate common name
Certificate issuer thumbprint, separated by commas if more than one
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
The existing Azure key vault secret URL, for example 'https://mykv.vault.azure.net:443/secrets/mysecrets/55ec7c4dc61a462bbc645ffc9b4b225f'
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Add-AzServiceFabricClusterCertificate -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -SecretIdentifier 'https://contoso03vault.vault.azure.net/secrets/contoso03vaultrg/7f7de9131c034172b9df37ccc549524f'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will add a certificate in the existing Azure key vault as a secondary cluster certificate.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:\> $pwd = ConvertTo-SecureString -String "123" -AsPlainText -Force PS c:\> add-AzServiceFabricClusterCertificate -ResourceGroupName 'Group2' -Name 'Contoso02SFCluster' -CertificateSubjectName 'Contoso.com' -CertificateOutputFolder 'c:\test' -CertificatePassword $pwd

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will create a self-signed certificate in the Azure key vault and upgrade the cluster to use it as a secondary cluster certificate.

maml:description.maml:para: Add nodes to the specific node type in the cluster.
Use Add-AzServiceFabricNode to add nodes to the specific node type. You just need to specify the number of nodes you want to add to a node type.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:> Add-AzServiceFabricNode -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -NumberOfNodesToAdd 2 -NodeTypeName 'nt1'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will add 2 nodes to the node type 'n1'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:\> $pwd = ConvertTo-SecureString -String 'Password$123456' -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> Add-AzServiceFabricNodeType -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -NodeType 'n2' -Capacity 5 -VmUserName 'adminName' -VmPassword $pwd

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will add a new NodeType 'n2' with capacity of 5, and the vm admin name is 'adminName'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appName = "testApp" PS C:\> Get-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -Name $appName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the application resource details for the application "testApp".

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> Get-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets a list of the applications under the cluster "testCluster".

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will get the application type details with the parameters specified, if it doesn't find the resource it will throw an exception.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appTypeName = "testAppType" PS C:\> $appTypeName = "v1" PS C:\> Get-AzServiceFabricApplicationTypeVersion -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -Name $appTypeName -Version

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the application type "testAppType" with version "v1", if it doesn't find the resource it will throw an exception.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appTypeName = "testAppType" PS C:\> Get-AzServiceFabricApplicationTypeVersion -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -Name $appTypeName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets a list of the application type versions defined under the specified cluster and type.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appName = "testApp" PS C:\> $serviceName = "testApp~testService" PS C:\> Get-AzServiceFabricService -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -ApplicationName $appName -Name $serviceName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the service resource details for the service "testApp~testService".

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appName = "testApp" PS C:\> Get-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -ApplicationName $appName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets a list of the services under the application "testApp".

maml:description.maml:para: Create new service fabric application under the specified resource group and cluster.

This cmdlet creates a new service fabric application under the specified resource group and cluster. The parameter -PackageUrl can be used to create the type version, If the type version already exits but its in 'Failed' state the cmdlet will ask if the user wants to recreate the type version. If it continues in 'Failed' state, the command will stop the process and throw an exception.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster.
Specify the name of the application type
Specify the application type version
Specify the application parameters as key/value pairs. These parameters must exist in the application manifest.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Continue without prompts
Specifies the maximum number of nodes on which to place an application
Specifies the minimum number of nodes where Service Fabric will reserve capacity for this application
Specify the name of the application
Specify the url of the application package sfpkg file
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the application parameters as key/value pairs. These parameters must exist in the application manifest.
Specify the name of the application type
Specify the application type version
Specify the name of the cluster.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Continue without prompts
Specifies the maximum number of nodes on which to place an application
Specifies the minimum number of nodes where Service Fabric will reserve capacity for this application
Specify the name of the application
Specify the url of the application package sfpkg file
Specify the name of the resource group.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName "testRG" -ClusterName "testCluster" -ApplicationTypeName "TestAppType" -ApplicationTypeVersion "v1" -Name "testApp" -ApplicationParameter @{key0="value0";key1=$null;key2="value2"}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates the application "testApp" under resource group "testRG" and cluster "testCluster". The application type "TestAppType" version "v1" should already exist in the cluster, and the application parameters should be defined in the application manifest otherwise the cmdlet will fail.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Specify -PackageUrl to create the application type version before creating the application.
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName "testRG" -ClusterName "testCluster" -ApplicationTypeName "TestAppType" -ApplicationTypeVersion "v1" -Name "testApp" -PackageUrl "https://sftestapp.blob.core.windows.net/sftestapp/testApp_1.0.sfpkg" -ApplicationParameter @{key0="value0";key1=$null;key2="value2"}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates the application type "TestAppType" version "v1" using the package url provided. After this, it will continue the normal process to create the application. If the application type version already exits and the provisioning state its in 'Failed' it will prompt to decide if the user wants to recreate the type version.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will create a new application type "testAppType" under the resource group and cluster specified.

maml:description.maml:para: Create new application type version under the specified resource group and cluster.

This cmdlet creates a new application type version using the package specified in -PackageUrl, this should be accessible through a REST endpoint for Azure Resource Manager to consume during deployment and contained The application packaged and zipped with the extension .sfpkg. This command will create the application type if it doesn't exist already.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster.
Specify the name of the application type
Specify the application type version
Specify the default values of the application parameters as key/value pairs. These parameters must exist in the application manifest.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Continue without prompts
Specify the url of the application package sfpkg file
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appTypeName = "testAppType" PS C:\> $version = "v1" PS C:\> $packageUrl = "https://sftestapp.blob.core.windows.net/sftestapp/testApp_1.0.sfpkg" PS C:\> New-AzServiceFabricApplicationTypeVersion -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -Name $appTypeName -Version $version -PackageUrl $packageUrl -Verbose

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will create an application type version "v1" under type "testAppType". The version in the application manifest contained in the package should have the same version as the one specified in -Version.

maml:description.maml:para: This command uses certificates that you provide or system generated self-signed certificates to set up a new service fabric cluster. It can use a default template or a custom template that you provide. You have the option of specifying a folder to export the self-signed certificates to or fetching them later from the key vault.

The New-AzServiceFabricCluster command uses certificates that you provide or system generated self-signed certificates to set up a new service fabric cluster. The template used can be a default template or a custom template that you provide. You have the option of specifying a folder to export the self-signed certificates or fetching them later from the key vault. If you are specifying a custom template and parameter file, you don't need to provide the certificate information in the parameter file, the system will populate these parameters. The four options are detailed below. Scroll down for explanations of each of the parameters.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the name of the resource group.

Certificate issuer thumbprint, separated by commas if more than one
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
The path to the template parameter file.
The existing Azure key vault secret URL, for example 'https://mykv.vault.azure.net:443/secrets/mysecrets/55ec7c4dc61a462bbc645ffc9b4b225f'
The path to the template file.
The password of the Vm.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Specify only the cluster size, the cert subject name, and the OS to deploy a cluster
command:example.dev:code:
$password = "Password#1234" | ConvertTo-SecureString -AsPlainText -Force $resourceGroupName = "quickstart-sf-group" $azureRegion = "southcentralus" $clusterDnsName = "{0}.{1}.cloudapp.azure.com" -f $resourceGroupName, $azureRegion $localCertificateFolder = "c:\certs"
Write-Output "Create cluster in '$azureRegion' with cert subject name '$clusterDnsName' and cert output path '$localCertificateFolder'"
New-AzServiceFabricCluster -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -Location $azureRegion -ClusterSize 5 -VmPassword $password -CertificateSubjectName $clusterDnsName -CertificateOutputFolder $localCertificateFolder -CertificatePassword $pass -OS WindowsServer2016Datacenter

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command specifies only the cluster size, the cert subject name, and the OS to deploy a cluster.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Specify an existing Certificate resource in a key vault and a custom template to deploy a cluster
command:example.dev:code:
$resourceGroupName = "test20" $templateParameterFile = "C:\service-fabric-secure-nsg-cluster-65-node-3-nodetype\azuredeploytest.parameters.json" $templateFile = "C:\azure-quickstart-templates\service-fabric-secure-nsg-cluster-65-node-3-nodetype\azuredeploy.json" $secretId = "https://test1.vault.azure.net:443/secrets/testcertificate4/56ec774dc61a462bbc645ffc9b4b225f"
New-AzServiceFabricCluster -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -TemplateFile $templateFile -ParameterFile $templateParameterFile -SecretIdentifier $secretId

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command specifies an existing Certificate resource in a key vault and a custom template to deploy a cluster.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Create a new cluster using a custom template. Specify a different resource group name for the key vault and have the system upload a new certificate to it
command:example.dev:code:
$password = "Password#1234" | ConvertTo-SecureString -AsPlainText -Force $resourceGroupName = "quickstart-sf-group" $keyVaultResourceGroupName = " quickstart-kv-group" $keyVaultName = "quickstart-kv" $azureRegion = "southcentralus" $clusterDnsName = "{0}.{1}.cloudapp.azure.com" -F $resourceGroupName, $azureRegion $localCertificateFolder = "~\Documents" $templateParameterFile = "C:\service-fabric-secure-nsg-cluster-65-node-3-nodetype\azuredeploytest.parameters.json" $templateFile = "C:\service-fabric-secure-nsg-cluster-65-node-3-nodetype\azuredeploy.json"
New-AzServiceFabricCluster -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -TemplateFile $templateFile -ParameterFile $templateParameterFile -CertificateOutputFolder $localCertificateFolder -CertificatePassword $password -KeyVaultResourceGroupName $keyVaultResourceGroupName -KeyVaultName $keyVaultName -CertificateSubjectName $clusterDnsName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new cluster using a custom template. Specify a different resource group name for the key vault and have the system upload a new certificate to it

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Bring your own Certificate and custom template and create a new cluster
command:example.dev:code:
$password = "Password#1234" | ConvertTo-SecureString -AsPlainText -Force $resourceGroupName = "test20" $keyVaultResourceGroupName = "test20kvrg" $keyVaultName = "test20kv" $localCertificateFile = "c:\Mycertificates\my2017Prodcert.pfx" $templateParameterFile = "~\Documents\GitHub\azure-quickstart-templates-parms\service-fabric-secure-nsg-cluster-65-node-3-nodetype\azuredeploytest.parameters.json" $templateFile = "~\GitHub\azure-quickstart-templates\service-fabric-secure-nsg-cluster-65-node-3-nodetype\azuredeploy.json"
New-AzServiceFabricCluster -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -TemplateFile $templateFile -ParameterFile $templateParameterFile -CertificateFile $localCertificateFile -CertificatePassword $password -KeyVaultResourceGroupName $keyVaultResourceGroupName -KeyVaultName $keyVaultName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will let you bring your own Certificate and custom template and create a new cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Create new service fabric service under the specified application and cluster.

This cmdlet allows to creating stateless or stateful services under the specified application. The service should exit in the application manifest and the type should be the same as the one in the manifest. The application name should be a prefix of the service name.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster.
Specify the name of the application.
Specify the name of the service.
Specify the default cost for a move. Higher costs make it less likely that the Cluster Resource Manager will move the replica when trying to balance the cluster
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Specify the instance count for the service
Indicates that the service uses the singleton partition scheme. Singleton partitions are typically used when the service does not require any additional routing.
Use for stateless service
Specify the service type name of the application, should exist in the application manifest.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appName = "testApp" PS C:\> $serviceName = "testApp~testService1" PS C:\> $serviceTypeName = "testStateless" PS C:\> New-AzServiceFabricService -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -ApplicationName $appName -Name $serviceName -Type $serviceTypeName -Stateless -InstanceCount -1 -PartitionSchemaSingleton -Verbose

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will create a new stateless service "testApp~testService1" with instance count -1 (on all the nodes).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appName = "testApp" PS C:\> $serviceName = "testApp~testService2" PS C:\> $serviceTypeName = "testStatefulType" PS C:\> New-AzServiceFabricService -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -ApplicationName $appName -Name $serviceName -Type $serviceTypeName -Stateful -TargetReplicaSetSize 3 MinReplicaSetSize 5

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will create a new stateful service "testApp~testService2" with a target of 5 nodes.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example removes the application "testApp" under the resource group "testRG" and cluster "testCluster".

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will remove the application type "testAppType" and all the version under it. If there are any applications created with this type, the command will throw an exception.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will remove the version "v1" under the type "testAppType". It there are any applications under this resource the command will throw an exception.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove a cluster certificate from being used for cluster security.
Use Remove-AzServiceFabricClusterCertificate to remove a cluster certificate from the cluster, as long as there is another valid certificate that is already in use in the cluster.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the certificate with thumbprint 5F3660C715EBBDA31DB1FFDCF508302348DE8E7A from being used for cluster security.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove nodes from the specific node type from a cluster.
Use Remove-AzServiceFabricNode to remove nodes from a specific node type from a cluster. The removal proceeds only if it meets cluster health metrics.

command:example.dev:code: PS c:> Remove-AzServiceFabricNode -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -NodeTypeName 'nt1' -NumberOfNodesToRemove 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will remove 2 nodes from the NodeType 'nt1'.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove a complete node type from a cluster.
Use the Remove-AzServiceFabricNodeType to remove all nodes from a specific node type and the node type from a cluster. This command cannot be used to delete the primary node type.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will remove NodeType 'nt1' from the cluster.

command:example.dev:code: PS c:\> Set-AzServiceFabricSetting -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -Section 'NamingService' -Parameter 'MaxFileOperationTimeout' -Value 5000

maml:description.maml:para: Change the Service Fabric upgrade type of the cluster.
Use Set-AzServiceFabricUpgradeType to set upgrade type to automatic or manual with specific Service Fabric code version.

Specify the name of the cluster
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:> Set-AzServiceFabricUpgradeType -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -UpgradeMode Automatic

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will set the cluster upgrade mode to automatic.

maml:description.maml:para: Update a service fabric application. This allows to update the application parameters and/or upgrade the application type version which will trigger an application upgrade.

This cmdlet can be used to update application parameters and upgrade the application type version. Updating the parameter will only change the model in ARM side, only when a new type version is used, the command will trigger an application upgrade. The type version specified should already be created in the cluster using New-AzServiceFabricApplicationTypeVersion .

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster.
Specify the name of the application
Specify the application type version
Specify the application parameters as key/value pairs. These parameters must exist in the application manifest.
Indicates whether to treat a warning health event as an error event during health evaluation.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Specifies the maximum percent of unhelthy partitions per service allowed by the health policy for the default service type to use for the monitored upgrade.
Specifies the maximum percent of unhelthy replicas per service allowed by the health policy for the default service type to use for the monitored upgrade.
Specifies the maximum percent of unhelthy services allowed by the health policy for the default service type to use for the monitored upgrade.
Specifies the action to take if the monitored upgrade fails. The acceptable values for this parameter are Rollback or Manual.
Indicates that the service host restarts even if the upgrade is a configuration-only change.
Specifies the duration, in seconds, after which Service Fabric retries the health check if the previous health check fails.

Specifies the duration, in seconds, that Service Fabric waits in order to verify that the application is stable before moving to the next upgrade domain or completing the upgrade. This wait duration prevents undetected changes of health right after the health check is performed.
Specifies the duration, in seconds, that Service Fabric waits before it performs the initial health check after it finishes the upgrade on the upgrade domain.
Specifies the maximum number of nodes on which to place an application
Specifies the minimum number of nodes where Service Fabric will reserve capacity for this application

Specifies the map of the health policy to use for different service types as a hash table in the following format: @ {"ServiceTypeName" : "MaxPercentUnhealthyPartitionsPerService,MaxPercentUnhealthyReplicasPerPartition,MaxPercentUnhealthyServices"}. For example: @{ "ServiceTypeName01" = "5,10,5"; "ServiceTypeName02" = "5,5,5" }
Specifies the maximum percentage of the application instances deployed on the nodes in the cluster that have a health state of error before the application health state for the cluster is error.
Specifies the maximum time, in seconds, that Service Fabric takes to upgrade a single upgrade domain. After this period, the upgrade fails.
Specifies the maximum time that Service Fabric waits for a service to reconfigure into a safe state, if not already in a safe state, before Service Fabric proceeds with the upgrade.
Specifies the maximum time, in seconds, that Service Fabric takes for the entire upgrade. After this period, the upgrade fails.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Arm ResourceId of the application.
Specify the application type version
Specify the application parameters as key/value pairs. These parameters must exist in the application manifest.
Indicates whether to treat a warning health event as an error event during health evaluation.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Specifies the maximum percent of unhelthy partitions per service allowed by the health policy for the default service type to use for the monitored upgrade.
Specifies the maximum percent of unhelthy replicas per service allowed by the health policy for the default service type to use for the monitored upgrade.
Specifies the maximum percent of unhelthy services allowed by the health policy for the default service type to use for the monitored upgrade.
Specifies the action to take if the monitored upgrade fails. The acceptable values for this parameter are Rollback or Manual.
Indicates that the service host restarts even if the upgrade is a configuration-only change.
Specifies the duration, in seconds, after which Service Fabric retries the health check if the previous health check fails.

Specifies the duration, in seconds, that Service Fabric waits in order to verify that the application is stable before moving to the next upgrade domain or completing the upgrade. This wait duration prevents undetected changes of health right after the health check is performed.
Specifies the duration, in seconds, that Service Fabric waits before it performs the initial health check after it finishes the upgrade on the upgrade domain.
Specifies the maximum number of nodes on which to place an application
Specifies the minimum number of nodes where Service Fabric will reserve capacity for this application

Specifies the map of the health policy to use for different service types as a hash table in the following format: @ {"ServiceTypeName" : "MaxPercentUnhealthyPartitionsPerService,MaxPercentUnhealthyReplicasPerPartition,MaxPercentUnhealthyServices"}. For example: @{ "ServiceTypeName01" = "5,10,5"; "ServiceTypeName02" = "5,5,5" }
Specifies the maximum percentage of the application instances deployed on the nodes in the cluster that have a health state of error before the application health state for the cluster is error.
Specifies the maximum time, in seconds, that Service Fabric takes to upgrade a single upgrade domain. After this period, the upgrade fails.
Specifies the maximum time that Service Fabric waits for a service to reconfigure into a safe state, if not already in a safe state, before Service Fabric proceeds with the upgrade.
Specifies the maximum time, in seconds, that Service Fabric takes for the entire upgrade. After this period, the upgrade fails.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
The application resource.

Specify the name of the cluster.
Indicates whether to treat a warning health event as an error event during health evaluation.

Specifies the maximum percent of unhelthy replicas per service allowed by the health policy for the default service type to use for the monitored upgrade.
Specifies the maximum percent of unhelthy services allowed by the health policy for the default service type to use for the monitored upgrade.
Specifies the action to take if the monitored upgrade fails. The acceptable values for this parameter are Rollback or Manual.

For example: @{ "ServiceTypeName01" = "5,10,5"; "ServiceTypeName02" = "5,5,5" }
Specifies the maximum percentage of the application instances deployed on the nodes in the cluster that have a health state of error before the application health state for the cluster is error.
Specifies the maximum time, in seconds, that Service Fabric takes to upgrade a single upgrade domain. After this period, the upgrade fails.

Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appName = "testApp" PS C:\> $version = "v2" PS C:\> $packageUrl = "https://sftestapp.blob.core.windows.net/sftestapp/testAppType_v2.sfpkg" PS C:\> New-AzServiceFabricApplicationTypeVersion -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -Name $appName -Version $version -PackageUrl $packageUrl -Verbose PS C:\> Update-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -ApplicationTypeVersion $version -Name $appName -ApplicationParameter @{key0="value0";key1=$null;key2="value2"}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will start an application upgrade to update the type version to "v2" which was created with New-AzServiceFabricApplicationTypeVersion . The application parameters used should be defined in the application manifest.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appName = "testApp" PS C:\> Update-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -Name $appName -MinimumNodes 1 -MaximumNodes 4 -Verbose

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will update the minimum and maximum number of nodes restriction for the application.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $resourceGroupName = "testRG" PS C:\> $clusterName = "testCluster" PS C:\> $appName = "testApp" PS C:\> $version = "v2" PS C:\> $packageUrl = "https://sftestapp.blob.core.windows.net/sftestapp/testAppType_v2.sfpkg" PS C:\> New-AzServiceFabricApplicationTypeVersion -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -Name $appName -Version $version -PackageUrl $packageUrl -Verbose PS C:\> Update-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -ApplicationTypeVersion $version -Name $appName -ApplicationParameter @{key0="value0";key1=$null;key2="value2"} -HealthCheckStableDurationSec 0 -HealthCheckWaitDurationSec 0 -HealthCheckRetryTimeoutSec 0 -UpgradeDomainTimeoutSec 5000 -UpgradeTimeoutSec 7000 -FailureAction Rollback -UpgradeReplicaSetCheckTimeoutSec 300 -ForceRestart

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will start an application upgrade to update the type version to "v2" and also sets some upgrade policy parameters that will take effect from the current upgrade.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Update-AzServiceFabricApplication -ResourceGroupName $resourceGroupName -ClusterName $clusterName -Name $appName -ApplicationParameter @{key0="value0";key1=$null;key2="value2"}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example updates the application parameters but these changes will only take effect until the next version upgrade to the application.

maml:description.maml:para: Update the durability tier or VmSku of a node type in the cluster.
Use Update-AzServiceFabricDurability to update durability or SKU of the cluster.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with azure.
Specify durability level.
Specify Service Fabric node type name.
Specify the SKU of the node type.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with azure.
Specify durability level.
Specify the name of the cluster.
Specify Service Fabric node type name.
Specifies the name of the resource group.
Specify the SKU of the node type.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:> Update-AzServiceFabricDurability -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -DurabilityLevel Silver -NodeType nt1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes durability tier of the NodeType 'nt1' to silver.

maml:description.maml:para: Update the reliability tier of the primary node type in a cluster.
Use Update-AzServiceFabricReliability to update reliability of the primary node type in a cluster.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the name of the resource group.
Specify the name of the cluster
Add node count automatically when changing reliability
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Reliability tier
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Add node count automatically when changing reliability
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.
Specify the name of the cluster
Reliability tier
Specify the name of the resource group.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:> Update-AzServiceFabricReliability -ResourceGroupName 'Group1' -Name 'Contoso01SFCluster' -ReliabilityLevel Silver

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the reliability tier of the primary node type to silver.
